I cant stress enough the unsustainability of linear economy! There’s no way the United States citizens need to buy 6 million cars every year.

Instead of owning everything (like buying a car, which is linear economy) we should be striving for more rental systems. For example, renting cars from the car companies, being able to switch cars and to return it when it has served its useful life (in which case the company can reuse/repurpose the car materials) or you don’t like it anymore (so another person can rent it instead of g¡having to create a new car for them). This is called circular economy, where things don’t get devaluated as fast, things become cheaper and we consume less resources 🌎

I've never thought about it that much.  I like buying locally make "stuff" to decorate my home with. Even my "African" art comes all the way from a Nigerian family living in Speedy Creek (Swift Currant, Saskatchewan)  just a couple hours down the road from here (Moose Jaw, Saskatchewan).  I like smaller well constructed houses because they are cheaper & easier to maintain.  Yes I know, apartment can be move planet friendly but I grew up 3 hours horse ride from the nearest other kids so living in a house in a city is all the closeness I can take.  (And yes I rode 6 hours in a day to go play with my neighbors.  Of course the 6 hours of horse back riding were the best part of the day.)  I like spending my day woodworking with scrap lumber from construction sites and lumber yards.  Outside of fruit, local farmers are our main source of produce.  The local Hutterite colony are great for stuff during the winter months when other local produces aren't growing anything.  I'm happy with what I have and know that it is an unfair share.  As far as I can, I try to use green energy and donate to organizations that help the rest of the world get what they need.

Think about this: people say that buying a Tesla isn't carbon neutral, but with the technology tesla is developing, we could eventually see more and more aspects of the production cycle be replaced with sustainable energy sources. The same technology that powers an electric car could feasibly power any machine. Additionally the area required for farming could be seriously reduced with hydroponic interiors farming technologies. Ironically, as global food demands increase, it may become significantly more cost effective to build farms in artificial, vertical habitats. Same thing goes with the consumption of fossil fuels: as a limited resource their price will increase with the demand for them, thus making sustainable energy sources more enticing. I'm not saying excessive consumerism is necessarily always good, but I don't think it's an automatic tradeoff between the amount of consumption and the health of the environment. We don't need to cut down on our lifestyles, just to find better ways to sustain them

I am so glad that our high level of consumption as a society is coming under the microscope. There is so much to dissect here - the why and the what and how. There is no way it can be covered in one video or comment - but I think, at least for me, the answer has been in simplification. I don’t believe we evolved to be constantly entertained or constantly busy, but the forces around us are constantly competing for our attention to make money and garner resources for themselves that the right/wrong/should/shouldn’t is forgotten. We end up being bombarded with shiny things, emotional ads, outrageous news headlines - and we lose our time to center on what we really need. We lose our ability to even really know what we need because there is always someone or something telling us exactly what that next thing is.
We need to simplify and break it down to basics and really question why we are spending our resources and the Earth’s on every thing.

Well, you’re right, if everyone lived like the top 0.1% we’d all be screwed and just by living in America or Canada we’re already living off the backs of poor people and people less fortunate than us. And it’s also true that happiness is only correlated with wealth to a point but after a certain point, it has absolutely no influence. I suppose modifying culture could be part of the solution. But while all cultures are different, they still have stages of maturity. I highly doubt that Bangladesh will do us all a favor and keep from consuming goods the way we do now when it becomes industrialized just because it’s the right thing to do. People are people after all. They’ll probably use air conditioning the same way we do or they’ll find something else to spend ridiculous amounts of resources on that we don’t care about. Sustainability won’t matter to them, and why should it? We didn’t have to worry about it when we industrialized, so why should they?

I guess what I’m saying is that it’s in credibly unlikely that we are going to found a governing body over the whole world and then pay taxes to it and evenly distribute our energy and resources to each other while singing kumbaya within the next 50-100 years. What we really need is innovation. We need to be able to enjoy our air conditioning and heaters while being sustainable and not needing 12 earths of land and resources. Or we need to find resources from elsewhere like asteroids.

We only have a few tools at our disposal to modify human behavior towards a collective outcome. The three major ones are violence, money, and culture. Normally these tools are used to force people to look out for the group rather than just themselves, and many times, they have been used to force people to look out for only the group at the expense of themselves. People became properties of the State. So we can’t go crazy with these tools. We really shouldn’t use violence. So that leaves us with money and culture. Culture takes too long to modify, so it might help a little bit, but not enough. We’re just going to have to create financial incentives to innovate our way out of this mess. And you can’t pay people to live a poor lifestyle to save the world... because there would be no financial incentive to do that. What you can do is give people a lot of money if they can figure out how to sustainably live in mansions so that the whole world can live in mansions without us needing 12 earths.

Last as a little side note, colder climates need more energy, heating is always going to take more energy than cooling, which is one reason why Sweden and Norway are still fairly heavy energy users per capita (electric cars are an issue because low temperatures can easily compromise your battery life and the range). Airconditioners use something called a COP (coefficient of performance which nowadays is usually between 3 and 4), while heaters/boilers can never be more than near 100% efficient. While isolation is the biggest solution to cutting cost and improving efficiency in both cases (smaller windows ... or triple pane with low emissity coating for those mansions).
Point being you can not simply divide the energy evenly, colder climates will need more, temperate climates (15-30C) the least probably, and hot climates are somewhere in between.
Same reason when you compare Canada and the US directly that it would be a fair comparison.

I think this video brings up very valid points, but in the context of Canada, neglects to mention just how gigantic Canada is in terms of physical area. Yes we have terrible public transit in most places, and large vehicles, but between our relitively small population, and large area, it is often quite difficult or even infeasable to have good public transportation. Further many areas of Canada have little to no alternatives to those "gas guzzling" vehicles, as, in rural areas there is spotty or non-existant snow removal systems, and there is rather extreem conditions in terms of cold, snow, and distance to work/ammenities that would prohibit walking or having a small car. Also many people in rural areas rely on the ability to tow/haul things with their vehicle for both everyday life, and work. I think that many people in Canada feel opposed to 'green initiatives' because those green ideas are often quite infeasable for many rural Canadians. This comment is not to say that those people are totally right, but just to bring up the point that many of those people have valid complaints. I think the idea of stopping climate change is largely supported/pushed by people from larger centers and warmer climates, so if we could help to include people from rural areas (without making them feel like we are attacking them) then they too could get onboard for fighting climate change. Thus I think an analysis of rural vs urban resource use, and the ways it can be reduced would be quite helpful in convincing the people who are not already on-board the stop-global-warming-train. You guys make excellent videos in terms of good sources, good science, and a well balanced argument, and I'd love to see a video from you guys that I could show to my rural friends that oppose climate change initaitives 🙃

I did the footprint calculations just now for myself using your tool and I was kinda surprised by the results, both positively and negatively:
-I don't eat nearly as much meat as others do, but I am always very concious of it and want to eat less meat and dairy than I do currently. Yet doing that would not have that much impact (like 0.2 earths less). Which I always thought was a huge deal.
-what really surprised me was my travel footprint (pre-corona): I don't fly and don't use a car, but I used to travel 140km daily to university (700km a week) by train. I always thought that was the best environment friendly way, but I never thought about how much it still was in terms of footprint:
Comparing pre-corona and corona times, going from 700 km traintravel to 0 reduced my footprints from 2.9 earths to 1.6!! thats a huge difference with just that one change!! currently with travelling once a week to another city for 120km weekly, I'm at 1.8 earths. This calculator probably underestimates the footprint a bit, but still.
So what I take away from this, is that I really should go live in the city that I work in and travel by bike, or work from home more often. Working from home may be one of the good trends from corona.

And what to do about going from 1.8 to <1. well yeah that's the challenge.
